title.narrative: Trapca TFF support to Trade Facilitation Facility
Trapca TFF support to Trade Facilitation Facility

description.narrative:
During the Ninth WTO Ministerial in 2013, the Government made a pledge support the Least-Developed Countries (LDCs) and low-income countries (LICs) in the implementation of the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA). The Government further announced that the Swedish funded trade policy training institute Trapca, would host such a program/facility.
The aim of the program is to support stakeholders from LDCs/LICs to increase their understanding of TFA, enhance their capacity for the implementation of TFA, and thus create opportunities for LDCs/LICs benefit from the Agreement.
Trade facilitation is the simplification, harmonization, standardization and modernization of trade procedures. It boosts trade by reducing costs and delays for traders, through measures that provide predictability, simplicity, transparency and uniformity in customs and other border procedures.
WTO agreement on trade facilitation is assessed, when implemented, contribute to the above. In order for developing countries to benefit from potential gains, the TFA contains commitments on trade-related support for this implementation.
Estimates of economic gains resulting from the Trade Facilitation Agreement vary widely. On a general level, the Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development (OECD) estimates that for every one-percent reduction in global trade costs, global incomes go up by USD 40 billion. The effects on job creation at the global level are estimated in the millions. The OECD anticipates that the combined effect of a comprehensive trade facilitation reform would reduce total trade costs by almost 14.5 per cent for low income countries.
Trapca has demonstrated good results in trade policy training for participants from LDCs and low-income countries since its inception in 2006. Trapca and Sweden have had a close working relationship since the Centre was established with Swedish funding and has throughout been kept operational mainly by Swedish funds. The fact that Lund University is Trapca's academic partner further strengthens the relationship with Sweden.
Trapca with its good reputation, clear African ownership, established education / training modules and existing systems for reporting and monitoring is assessed to be a good implementing partner for the programme. This based on the assessment to ability to achieve results, cost-effective project management and existing systems and routines for reporting / monitoring of the above.

Regeringen gjorde i samband med WTO:s nionde ministerkonferens en utfästelse om finansiellt stöd till de minst utvecklade länderna (MUL) och låginkomstländer till stöd för genomförandet av avtalet om förenklade handelsprocedurer (TFA). Regeringen uttryckte specifikt att det svenskfinansierade institutet för handelspolitisk utbildning, Trapca, skulle stå värd för en sådan facilitet.
Syftet är att stödja intressenter från MUL/låginkomstländer i ökad förståelse om TFA, förstärkt kapacitet för implementeringen av TFA, och därmed ökade möjligheter att dra nytta av TFA.
Förenkling av handelsprocedurer innebär harmonisering, standardisering och modernisering av handelsprocedurer. Dessa förenklingar gynnar handel genom att minska kostnaderna för de som handlar, detta genom åtgärder som bidrar med förutsägbarhet, insyn och uniformitet i tull- och andra relaterade procedurer.
WTO-avtalet om förenklade handelsprocedurer bedöms, när implementerat, bidra till ovan. TFA innehåller åtganden om stöd till utvecklingsländer för denna implementering.
Uppskattningar kring ekonomiska vinster av TFA varierar, men OECD bedömer generellt att för varje enprocents-minskning i globala handelskostnader ökar globala inkomster med 40 miljarder dollar. Effekterna på sysselsättningsskapande uppskattas till miljontals, också av OECD. En genomgripande reform på området för handelsprocedurer, där TFA-implementering skulle utgöra en signifikant del, skulle minska handelskostnader med ca 14,5% för låginkomstländer, enligt OECDs beräkningar.
Trapca har visat goda resultat inom handelspolitisk utbildning för deltagare från MUL och låginkomstländer sedan starten 2006. Trapca och Sverige har en nära relation då institutet etablerades med svenska medel och har sedan dess också drivits av framförallt svenska medel. Det faktum att Lunds universitet också är Trapcas akademiska partner förstärker relationerna ytterligare.
Trapca med sin goda renommé, tydligt afrikanska ägarskap, upparbetade utbildnings-/träningsmoduler och existerande system för rapportering och uppföljning bedöms vara en god samarbetspart för ändamålet. Detta utifrån bedömning att uppnå resultat, kostnadseffektiv projektdrift och existerande system för genomförande och rapportering/uppföljning av detsamma.

The TFTF longer term objective at impact level (referred to as “development goal”) concurs with the overarching Trapca development objective: “Improved possibilities for LDCs and low-income sub-Saharan African (SSA) countries to benefit from integration into the world economy through enhanced international and regional trade which will contribute to sustainable growth and poverty reduction.” The project objective refers to the purpose of the TFTF specifically. In terms of Sida followup, it was proposed that emphasis is put on what Trapca refers to as expected short-term outcomes. These are in fact closer to outputs, which is a realistic ambition for this project, given that it lasts onlyjust over a year:i. National and regional trade facilitation stakeholders in LDC/LIC have taken part of existing knowledge about the TFA and globally acknowledged best practices of implementation of TFA obligations.ii. The establishment and management by TFTF of a network of TFA academia with the aim to generate knowledge about TFA and its consequences for LDCs/LICs.iii. Private sector trade facilitation stakeholders from LDC/LIC involved in the Trapca Trade Facilitation Training Facility

description.narrative: The Trade Facilitation courses proved successful and in demand as TF becomes more and more important in Africa. This is partly due to the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement having been signed and implementation moving to the top of the agenda. The TF courses are since 2016 integrated in trapca's normal curriculum. During 2015 8 TFA Executive leadership courses were held with a total of 243 participants and the integration of TF courses into the MSc-curriculum commenced. In total, 19 executive and academic courses were held, and 595 participants drawn from trapca's target beneficiary countries were trained. From 2016 the courses were offered as part of trapca normal course offerings. In 2017 eight executive courses were held for Members of the National Trade Facilitation Committees in the following eight countries: Lesotho, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, Niger, Togo, Uganda and Zambia.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
